subtitle: as we revisit we evaluate and analyze I
remember someone coming to speak to me
who grew up in a very religious home
it's a very dogmatic home is the way
they put it
everything was this is what you must do
and if you didn't you got punished
either directly or vertically or subtly
and in some ways also excommunicated you
were rejected and this person tells me
how he was rejected by his parents and
by his community because he chose to
challenge and he says a lot of the
religion was very abusive and he doesn't
want to even look at it anymore so I
said them look is there any beautiful
experience that you recall from your
childhood yes that's what makes it so
sad I feel I was robbed some of the most
beautiful memories I had it's our
grandparents at the Seder sometimes in
the synagogue they were all contaminated
and now it's like a snowball so I just
reject the whole thing because I don't
have to separate I said that's exactly
the job is to separate you don't throw
out the baby with the bathwater
emotionally it's difficult to do but
that's what we need to do when we
revisit that's what we're exactly what
we're trying to do we're revisiting it
looking at it tinkering with it and
saying okay what part of it was negative
what part of it was positive and when
you do this in a very deliberate and
committed way you begin to be able to
touched extract well a few years later
working with him and working on himself
and I give him a lot of credit because
it was very painful he was able to
reconnect to certain things because he
revisited it had he had not he would
have just rejected the entire thing so
it's like almost in a talk about medical
level thinking a physical level
sometimes a person gets injured and they
don't want to use that part of their
body anymore because they were afraid to
but that part of the body is part of who
you are you want to separate from the
injury the memory the sadness the
Dibble billete ting element of it and
reclaim that which is yours but
revisiting is the first step because
that allows us to separate to
distinguish between the healthy and
unhealthy between the toxic and the pure
between the dysfunctional and the
functional and that revisiting is vital
it's what we call in hebrew hezbollah
nefesh it's an accountability
soul-searching introspection not
allowing yourself to just either embrace
something blindly or rejected blindly
because we were hurt it's revisiting it
and looking for ways to appreciate that
which was good and see what was negative
you
